reviews.review_msg: Dr. Rintoul is a very caring professor for physiology. His lectures are so detailed that I can easily understand almost everything he says clearly. Also, his exams are easy as long as you put in the work and know the material. I highly recommend him for physiology related classes.

Dr. Rintoul was an amazing prof. he is super passionate about what he teaches so it makes it easy to listen to him lecture. The animal portion of this class is very dense with content but his slides simplify everything perfectly. would take his class again.
Dr. Rintoul is a very kind professor and his lectures are very engaging. The animal physiology portion of this course is pretty lecture heavy so be prepared to study a lot. Highly recommend.

I feel like some of the recent reviews are a bit harsh. Yes, his lectures are dense, but if you put in the effort to study (starting 6 days to a week before exams), you should be well-prepared. Flashcards are essential for this course. Gordon is also quick to respond to emails and is willing to explain concepts more than once if you're confused.

the best prof I've ever had by far. Yes his lectures are very heavy, but he explains everything super clearly and without fail, TELLS YOU what's going to be on the exam. If you stay on top of your stuff and go to class, you'll be fine. In my opinion, the recent reviews are quite harsh as this prof tells you and hints what to focus on when studying
Professor was fine. His lectures are very heavy and exams have really hard questions which dont even make sense. Overall he is fine but he just needs to make his exams easier.

really hard course. the tutorials of this course are based on a group project and no other prep for midterms and final, basically you self study. this prof also has too many slides in his lectures which makes it so hard to understand. unfortunately, he always teaches so you can't avoid him.

His lectures are very heavy. He literally has up to 75 lecture slides for a 50 min lecture. Also note that these slides are full with so much info. I hated his section of the course. the professsor teaching the plant section is slightly better in terms of lectures as he only has around 20-25 lecture slides and tests a little easier than this one.

Gordon was a great prof. He has a clear knowledge and passion for the subject and it made learning the material a lot easier. Gordon's lecture notes are quite heavy content-wise, but he is always willing to answer questions and discuss. Tutorials will require a group project, but the marking was quite lenient.
Gordon is a really great professor. This class was one of my favourites and would always set up for a great day. He speaks clearly and throws a joke in every now and then.
explains the physiology and mechanisms clearly, slides are easy to follow. exam is straightforward, no surprises. TIP: use the learning objectives as study guides.

Dr. Rintoul made the lectures very clear and breaks everything down and interesting to learn. He is clear of what to expect on the midterm and final so there aren't any surprises as long as you study. Very approachable for questions and encourages them. But do study for a good mark as the course itself is very heavy but love Dr. Rintoul for a prof.

Dr. Rintoul is by far by favourite prof at SFU. I loved his lectures and he was the first prof to make Biology actually interesting. He is approachable and friendly, and tests were fair. I recommend anyone in a science major to take this course. Want and would totally take any class by him again!

Dr. Rintoul is such a great professor, he is always open to questions from students and is very passionate about physiology. His exams are also fairly straightforward, so if you get the chance, take this course with him!

BISC 205 is a great course, but the plant side is pretty boring. Jim goes painfully into detail about plant growth and isn't very clear on what is expected for the exam. He has a strong accent and mumbles, making lectures difficult to understand (sit at the front). My best advice is to study well in advance for his exams. He also marks quite tough.

He is a very nice and caring man that cares for students. Howver, he is not the best prof. Very hard to hear and often had to interrupt during midterms and finals because students didnt understand his content. His format for mc isnt the best, and didnt give us a practice midterm as he, “procrastinates too”. If im paying for uni, I dont want this

The person who gave him a rating of 1 was likely a student who complains frequently. If you put in the time and effort to study, you'll definitely do well in the course. When I attended Professor Mattsson's office hours, he was friendly and took the time to explain difficult concepts, which really helped clarify my understanding.

Impossible to understand. Didn't even attend lecture because it was pointless, ppl would get up and leave mid lecture. Tests r marked tediously and was nothing like review we were given. Seems like a very nice + knowledgable guy but it's just a shame you can't hear/understand a word he's saying. Very cute dog he brings to class sometimes!

lectures were all over the place. He taught so many complex processes and the midterm had the simplest stuff on it that you would tend to overlook while studying. Got tested on specific examples from the notes and none of the hard stuff was on it which was frustrating.

I really enjoyed Jim's lectures, they were clear straight forward and easy to listen to. Midterm was easy if you put effort into the course. His office hours + review sessions were very helpful as well, he will explain any concepts you dont understand. 

(Tutorials were annoying, but I dont think that was so much his fault but rather my ta)

Aaron is a solid professor for the plant content in the class. His lectures are clear and well-organized. He also goes over exam content beforehand so you will always be prepared for the midterm. Always willing to answer questions and help in case some material confuses you.
Makes learning plants interesting, very straight forward on what will be on the exams.

I hate plants but Aron Weir made it actually interesting and taught it in a way that was easy to learn. Tests were super straightforward. Super enjoyable class that I would highly recommend to any science major. 100% would take again and one of my favourite classes and profs at SFU so far.
Aron is awesome! His midterms were pretty straightforward, no tricks as he mentioned. I hope he continues teaching!

Aron is a great professor, he was always available to help students and was always open to questions during lectures. Exams were not too hard, and the content was fairly straightforward. I must say, the course was a bit boring, but that might be because it is my fourth time learning about photosynthesis.

SFU should def make him a permanent prof and not just a sessional. I literally hate plant biology with every ounce of my body but Aron made it super easy and fun to learn. His lectures were super engaging and clear, and he's super lenient with marking and gives part marks for answers! Take him if you have a chance. Also sfu pls let him teach 337 :D

His lectures are clear and comprehensible, and he is super approachable to go to for help. His lectures are clear, and exams have no surprises, but definitely still study for a good mark. I would say he is an easy prof but the material can be a bit challenging but he makes his lectures very engaging and I look forward going to his class.

Prof. Weir is fantastic! Despite initial concerns about the lack of reviews, taking his course was definitely a great decision. His engaging lectures effectively break down and explain concepts. The exams are fair; focus on the learning objectives and pre-lecture readings for success!
